oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Report of Confederate killed, wounded, missing and escaped at Fort Donelson with published clipping
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Registers, lists, etc.; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Donelson, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Casualties; War casualties
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Report of the Confederate soldiers from Tennessee, Kentucky, Texas, Arkansas, Alabama, Mississippi, and Virginia killed, wounded, missing, or escaped from Fort Donelson. Shows a total of 15,246 engaged, 949 wounded (not surrendered), 273 killed, 11,738 surrendered, 2,286 missing, 38 wounded (surrendered), and 987 total wounded. Published clipping of total losses for Federals and Confederates in 1861-1862 on reverse.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Confederate States of America -- War Dept.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Federal General Ulysses S. Grant began an attack on Fort Donelson on February 11, 1862, in an attempt to open up the Cumberland River for Union access. Confederate General Gideon Pillow was effectively in command of the Confederates besieged in the fort and attempted a breakout before being beaten back. Nominal Confederate commanders Floyd and Johnson turned official command over to Pillow, who surrendered after Federal reinforcements arrived on February 16, 1862.
